channel.title: Money Pouch
channel.description: How would i go about lifting the limit of 2147m cash in money Pouch. As seen in Ikov and other servers giving one the ability to hold 12b or more. I know you have to change code from int to long but idk exactly where.

why do you need such a horrible economy
[/quote]

REFER A FRIEND GET 50 MIL[/quote]fifty million is a mere coin in the stack when you get up to nine quintillion two hundred twenty-three quadrillion three hundred seventy-two trillion thirty-six billion eight hundred fifty-four million seven hundred seventy-five thousand eight hundred seven coins.

item.title: Money Pouch
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

I literally said why I did the cheap method I provided.

It was to keep the value an integer and not modify the packet. That would make it so it’s a server-sided only update, and the players wouldn’t have to download a new client (most people don’t have a client updater, only cache).

Read full topic

A “cheap” way you could do this, without changing the value of the integer to a long or etc, would be to add a second integer that would hold all your “billions”. (not that it matters if you changed it to a long…)

[/quote][/quote]

i dont understand why you’re one of the most stuck-up people on this site tbh

why do you always opt the “cheap” way, or a “quick example” or a “written fast” or “sloppy code”, give him something decent like the rest of the server helpers on this forum. tell him how to change his money pouch packet and the size of the packet to work with longs

done. apologies for any inconveniences caused to op

item.title: Money Pouch
item.dc:creator: @djzone djzone
item.description:
@djzone wrote:

[quote=“sk8rdude461, post:11, topic:550021”][quote author=djzone link=topic=668897.msg4473632#msg4473632 date=1424533939]

ya lol package com; definitely in reply box

i understand it was an example but at least give an example that is plausible and worth adding

OP look at Zymus’ posts about changing the packets to work with longs rather than ints
[/quote]

Yeah, this part:

[code=java] private static int money = 999999999;
private static int billions = 0;

    public static void main(String[] args) {
            addMoney(1);
            addMoney(1000);
            addMoney(1999999999);
            addMoney(Integer.MAX_VALUE);
            System.out.println("Resetting money to 0");
            billions = money = 0;
            addMoney(10000);
    }
    
    public static void addMoney(int moneyToAdd) {
            if (moneyToAdd < 1)// If no money to add, don't continue in the method
                    return;
            while (moneyToAdd > 999999999) {// if money to add is greater than
                                                                            // 999.999m
                    moneyToAdd -= 1000000000;
                    billions++;
            }
            money += moneyToAdd;
            while (money > 999999999) {// if money to add is greater than 999.999m
                    money -= 1000000000;
                    billions++;
            }
            System.out.println("Cash: " + getCash());
    }
    
    private static String getCash() {
            if(billions > 0)
                    return billions + "B and " + format(money) + " coins";
            else
                    return format(money) + " coins";
    }
    
    public static String format(int num) {
            return NumberFormat.getInstance().format(num);
    }[/code]

^ was written in the reply box.[/quote]

i understand it was an example but at least give an example that is plausible and worth adding

Read full topic

item.description:

If you’ve got no real contribution to the thread, do not reply. It is even stated in the rules.
My code was an example, which was written in the reply box and tested on an online compiler.

Above is an example of what I’m talking about.
With this method, you technically can carry up to 2147 billion billions (so 2,147,000,000 * 2,147,000,000).

Hey thanks so much but where exactly would I place this without screwing everything up haha because
I have done quite alot of messing up trying to mess with the money pouch.

As I stated above, the code provided was an example. You were not supposed to copy and paste anything.
Take what zymus said into consideration:

Another thing you can do is have a MoneyPouch class that’s backed by a BigInteger.

And if you don’t understand what you’re doing, you should look at some java tutorials.
http://docs.oracle.com/javase/tutorial/java/index.html
http://docs.oracle.com/javase/tutorial/java/javaOO/classes.html[/quote]

item.title: Money Pouch
item.dc:creator: @djzone djzone
item.description:
@djzone wrote:

[quote=“sk8rdude461, post:3, topic:550021”]I’d do it server sided and screw updating the client.
A “cheap” way you could do this, without changing the value of the integer to a long or etc, would be to add a second integer that would hold all your “billions”. (not that it matters if you changed it to a long…)

[code=java]package com;

import java.text.NumberFormat;

public class MoneyTest {
private static int money = 999999999;
private static int billions = 0;

public static void main(String[] args) {
	addMoney(1);
	addMoney(1000);
	addMoney(1999999999);
	addMoney(Integer.MAX_VALUE);
	System.out.println("Resetting money to 0");
	billions = money = 0;
	addMoney(10000);
}

public static void addMoney(int moneyToAdd) {
	if (moneyToAdd < 1)// If no money to add, don't continue in the method
		return;
	while (moneyToAdd > 999999999) {// if money to add is greater than
									// 999.999m
		moneyToAdd -= 1000000000;
		billions++;
	}
	money += moneyToAdd;
	while (money > 999999999) {// if money to add is greater than 999.999m
		money -= 1000000000;
		billions++;
	}
	System.out.println("Cash: " + getCash());
}

private static String getCash() {
	if(billions > 0)
		return billions + "B and " + format(money) + " coins";
	else
		return format(money) + " coins";
}

public static String format(int num) {
	return NumberFormat.getInstance().format(num);
}

}[/code]
The output from above:

Cash: 1B and 0 coins Cash: 1B and 1,000 coins Cash: 3B and 999 coins Cash: 5B and 147,484,646 coins Resetting money to 0 Cash: 10,000 coins

Above is an example of what I’m talking about.
With this method, you technically can carry up to 2147 billion billions (so 2,147,000,000 * 2,147,000,000).[/quote]

wat on erth :rolleyes:

Read full topic

item.title: Money Pouch
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

Another thing you can do is have a MoneyPouch class that’s backed by a BigInteger. That way you can have literally a nearly unlimited amount of money. Then, when you go to deposit or withdraw, just make sure you have enough money in there. The max value for for a BigInteger would be greater than 646,311,401 digits long. Granted, the larger the number, the more memory it takes because the value backed by a byte array. The max value would be some computation of Integer.MAX_VALUE bytes.

Read full topic

item.title: Money Pouch
item.dc:creator: @kobra828 kobra828
item.description:
@kobra828 wrote:

[quote=“sk8rdude461, post:3, topic:550021”]I’d do it server sided and screw updating the client.
A “cheap” way you could do this, without changing the value of the integer to a long or etc, would be to add a second integer that would hold all your “billions”. (not that it matters if you changed it to a long…)

[code=java]package com;

import java.text.NumberFormat;

public class MoneyTest {
private static int money = 999999999;
private static int billions = 0;

public static void main(String[] args) {
	addMoney(1);
	addMoney(1000);
	addMoney(1999999999);
	addMoney(Integer.MAX_VALUE);
	System.out.println("Resetting money to 0");
	billions = money = 0;
	addMoney(10000);
}

public static void addMoney(int moneyToAdd) {
	if (moneyToAdd < 1)// If no money to add, don't continue in the method
		return;
	while (moneyToAdd > 999999999) {// if money to add is greater than
									// 999.999m
		moneyToAdd -= 1000000000;
		billions++;
	}
	money += moneyToAdd;
	while (money > 999999999) {// if money to add is greater than 999.999m
		money -= 1000000000;
		billions++;
	}
	System.out.println("Cash: " + getCash());
}

private static String getCash() {
	if(billions > 0)
		return billions + "B and " + format(money) + " coins";
	else
		return format(money) + " coins";
}

public static String format(int num) {
	return NumberFormat.getInstance().format(num);
}

}[/code]
The output from above:

Cash: 1B and 0 coins Cash: 1B and 1,000 coins Cash: 3B and 999 coins Cash: 5B and 147,484,646 coins Resetting money to 0 Cash: 10,000 coins

Above is an example of what I’m talking about.
With this method, you technically can carry up to 2147 billion billions (so 2,147,000,000 * 2,147,000,000).[/quote]

and where exactly would i need to put this to work?

Read full topic

item.title: Money Pouch
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

I’d do it server sided and screw updating the client.
A “cheap” way you could do this, without changing the value of the integer to a long or etc, would be to add a second integer that would hold all your “billions”. (not that it matters if you changed it to a long…)

[code=java]package com;

import java.text.NumberFormat;

public class MoneyTest {
private static int money = 999999999;
private static int billions = 0;

public static void main(String[] args) {
	addMoney(1);
	addMoney(1000);
	addMoney(1999999999);
	addMoney(Integer.MAX_VALUE);
	System.out.println("Resetting money to 0");
	billions = money = 0;
	addMoney(10000);
}

public static void addMoney(int moneyToAdd) {
	if (moneyToAdd < 1)// If no money to add, don't continue in the method
		return;
	while (moneyToAdd > 999999999) {// if money to add is greater than
									// 999.999m
		moneyToAdd -= 1000000000;
		billions++;
	}
	money += moneyToAdd;
	while (money > 999999999) {// if money to add is greater than 999.999m
		money -= 1000000000;
		billions++;
	}
	System.out.println("Cash: " + getCash());
}

private static String getCash() {
	if(billions > 0)
		return billions + "B and " + format(money) + " coins";
	else
		return format(money) + " coins";
}

public static String format(int num) {
	return NumberFormat.getInstance().format(num);
}

}[/code]
The output from above:

Cash: 1B and 0 coins Cash: 1B and 1,000 coins Cash: 3B and 999 coins Cash: 5B and 147,484,646 coins Resetting money to 0 Cash: 10,000 coins

Above is an example of what I’m talking about.
With this method, you technically can carry up to 2147 billion billions (so 2,147,000,000 * 2,147,000,000).

Read full topic
